body: New Yorkers, who have received word in recent days that the city's bridges are in serious disrepair, should take a good look at their landmark churches as they gather for Christmas services. Here are scenes from some of New York City's historic places of worship: * The great rose window at the 126-year-old St. Elias Byzantine Catholic Church in the
title: New York City Churches Urgently Need Repairs

body: Ten officers in the elite Tactical Narcotics Team are under investigation after allegations were made that they mistreated prisoners and lied about evidence to shore up shaky arrests and justify illegal searches, high-ranking police officials said yesterday. A lieutenant, three sergeants and six police officers from the Brooklyn North Tactical
title: 10 Detectives Face an Inquiry On False Data

body: The strike this week by 2,100 private sanitation workers is the latest shock wave from a little-publicized decision by New York City two years ago to prolong the use of its biggest garbage dump. The decision was to more than double the price the city charged private haulers to dump garbage at the Fresh Kills landfill in Staten Island. That set off
title: How a Small Policy Change Led to a Big Garbage Strike

body: Bulging mounds of black garbage bags started piling up on the sidewalks in front of New York City businesses yesterday as the 2,100 members of the teamsters union local who collect the trash went on strike for higher pay. Union members, who voted to strike a week ago but delayed the walkout at Mayor David N. Dinkins's request, voted 360 to 117 to
title: Strike Ties Up Trash Hauling For Businesses

body: Lech Walesa, apparently more popular in North America than at home, easily won a majority of the absentee votes in the Polish presidential election that were cast in the United States and Canada, according to tallies by Polish officials and the national radio and television network. Mr. Walesa, the Solidarity leader, won 60 percent of the the
title: EVOLUTION IN EUROPE; In U.S., Walesa Wins Easily

body: MANUFACTURERS of polystyrene, the lightweight plastic packaging material, have been struggling for two years to improve their environmental image by establishing a recycling program. But all of their efforts may have been undone by the decision earlier this month by the McDonald's Corporation to switch from plastic foam to paper packaging for its
title: A Setback for Polystyrene

body: Parishioners cried yesterday when told that a Brooklyn statue of a murdered priest who championed democracy in Poland had been damaged by vandals who scrawled in black paint: "For Lenin and Stalin." The statue, dedicated on Oct. 28, honors Jerzy Popieluszko, a Catholic priest in Poland who was killed six years ago for his anti-Communist statements
title: Statue of Slain Polish Priest Is Vandalized

body: James C. Harrison, an artist who had his first one-man exhibition at age 58, died on Saturday at his home in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn. He was 64 years old. He died of liver failure, said his dealer, Lori Ledis of the Ledisflam Gallery in SoHo. Mr. Harrison was born in Detroit. He studied briefly at the Cranbrook Academy of Art in
title: James C. Harrison, Brooklyn Artist, 64

body: A 16-year-old Brooklyn youth was arrested yesterday and charged with knocking down and dragging an 81-year-old nun as he tried to snatch her purse as he rode by on a bicyle Wednesday. Sister Joseph Concepta Farrell broke her hip and left wrist, said a police spokeswoman. She had been returning to St. Cecilia's Convent at 21 Monitor Street in the
title: Arrest in Robbery of a Nun

body: Shortly after the strike at The Daily News began 16 days ago, The News started recruiting homeless people from shelters across New York City to work as street vendors, advocates for the homeless say. In some cases, News employees drove up to shelters or other places where the homeless gather and dropped off bundles of freshly printed papers. Some,
title: Daily News Uses Homeless to Sell Paper

body: Wanda Panfil, the woman an ailing Grete Waitz said she had to beat to win the New York City Marathon for an unprecedented 10th time, proved the nine-time champion an accurate prophet of her own doom yesterday by doing just what Waitz had fearfully predicted: She started out strong in Staten Island, pulled away from the pack in Brooklyn and never
title: NEW YORK CITY MARATHON; Panfil Starts Fast, Holds Off Challenge

title: Outdoors; Shorter Striped Bass Restrictions

title: Census Workers Remember Resistance and Lies

body: LEAD: In an unusual departure from the power of incumbency, at least a half-dozen Democratic state legislators in New York City face stiff challenges in the Sept. 11 primary, which is usually tantamount to election in the predominantly Democratic city. title: Primaries in New York City Include Challenges to Incumbent Legislators

body: LEAD: A Federal judge has ruled that cocaine and cash seized in the apartment of a Brooklyn man cannot be used as evidence against him because the ploy used by the authorities to enter the home - posing as gas company workers and falsely warning of an imminent gas explosion - could not be condoned. title: Judge Bars Evidence Seized by Agents in 'Gas Leak Inspector' Trick

body: LEAD: Underground oil spills are difficult to photograph or visualize - no beaches covered with black goo, no sticky birds. title: The Nation; Ugly Reminders of the Oil That Went Underground

body: LEAD: STACEY FARLEY'S portfolio of hand-painted decorative tiles shows an array of the fanciful and creative.
